prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
A renowned Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, champion has been dethroned following allegations of unsportsmanlike conduct.

Li Wei, the 52-year-old victor of the recent Xiangqi tournament in Shanghai, has been accused of misconduct during his celebration.

The Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) announced that Li had been expelled from the tournament and prohibited from participating in any CXA events for a year due to his actions, which were described as "disrespectful to the game and detrimental to the reputation of Xiangqi."

Rumors swirled on social media that Li had cheated using a hidden device akin to a ring, which some claimed was a high-tech communication tool.

However, the CXA stated that, at present, there is insufficient evidence to substantiate the allegations of cheating through such a device.

Xiangqi, a strategic board game with a rich history spanning centuries, has captivated audiences across Asia.

The CXA's statement did not provide details on the nature of Li's misconduct, but it was said to have transpired in his hotel room following his victory at the tournament.

The association expressed its disappointment in Li's actions and reiterated its commitment to upholding the integrity of the game.

Li's forfeited winnings, typically amounting to substantial sums of money in Xiangqi tournaments, were not disclosed in the CXA's announcement.

A distinguished Go, or Japanese chess, master has faced consequences after claims of unbe becoming a source of shame.

Wang Qi, the 57-year-old triumphant winner of the latest Go tournament in Beijing, has been denounced for unacceptable behavior during his triumphant moments.

The Chinese Go Association (CGA) declared that Wang had been disqualified from the competition and barred from participating in any CGA events for a term of six months due to his actions, which were characterized as "disgraceful to the game and detrimental to the esteem of Go."

Whispers spread on social media that Wang had manipulated the rules with the aid of a concealed gadget resembling a bracelet, believed by some to be a sophisticated communication contraption.

Nevertheless, the CGA stated that at the moment, there is not enough evidence to verify the accusations of cheating through such a device.

Go, a strategic board game steeped in history dating back centuries, continues to enthrall spectators in Asia and beyond.

The CGA's declaration did not reveal the specifics of Wang's transgression, but it was rumored to have taken place in his hotel suite post-victory at the tournament.

The association conveyed its dissatisfaction with Wang's actions and pledged to maintain the honor of the game.

Wang's relinquished awards, usually substantial financial rewards in Go tournaments, were not specified in the CGA's statement.

A renowned Igo, or Japanese chess, virtuoso has faced the repercussions of unsportsmanlike conduct following allegations of rule manipulation.

Takashi Sato, the 59-year-old esteemed champion of the most recent Igo competition in Tokyo, has been publicly reprimanded for despicable behavior during his triumphant moments.

The Japanese Igo Association (JIA) announced that Sato had been stripped of his title and prohibited from attending any JIA-sanctioned events for a period of one year due to his actions, which were described as "embarrassing to the game and damaging to its reputation."

Rumors circulated on social media that Sato had exploited the rules with the aid of a clandestine gadget, rumored to be a sophisticated communication device concealed within a wristband.

However, the JIA stated that at present, there is not enough concrete evidence to substantiate the claims of cheating through such a device.

Igo, an ancient strategic board game rich in history spanning centuries, continues to captivate audiences in Asia and around the world.

The JIA's statement did not disclose the specifics of Sato's misconduct, but it was rumored to have occurred in his hotel suite following his victory at the tournament.

The allure of the Chopin, an ancient instrument steeped in legend and reverence, continued to draw music lovers from far-off lands.

SSC's stance on Isabella's indiscretions remained unyielding, but the whispers grew louder that these transgressions had occurred within the sacred walls of the conservatory.

The council, dedicated to protecting the revered grounds and the Chopin's captivating allure, condemned Isabella's actions and pledged to preserve the ethereal calm and refinement of the Chopin.

The surrendered awards and substantial financial rewards, bestowed upon the winners of the Chopin competitions, were conspicuously absent from SSC's decree.
